content:
UK/EU

UK Brexit Minister Raab said he is confident a Brexit deal is within sight and noted they are aiming to reach a deal at the October council but there is room for leeway. (Newswires)

EU's Brexit Negotiator Barnier said we are prepared to offer a partnership with the UK such as has never been with any other third country. There were also comments from the German Foreign Ministry that there will be no special rules for a post-Brexit UK although German Finance Minister Scholz stated a no-deal Brexit is no solution as economies are too linked, while French Finance Minister Le Maire also commented that avoiding a hard Brexit in the UK is in the EU’s interest. (Newswires)

EU is planning a counter-initiative to China's belt and road. (WIWO)


COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -2.566M vs. Exp. -0.686M (Prev. -5.836M). (Newswires)

Reports note a dock closure at Venezuela's main oil Port of Jose which may delay up to 5mln bbls of crude to Rosneft. (Newswires)

Senior Iraqi oil official stated that OPEC should discuss how to make up for a drop in Iranian oil supply and commented that the oil market will face big supply shortage post-Iran sanctions. (Newswires)

IEA's Executive Director Birol sees oil markets tightening towards end-year citing strong demand, Venezuela's falling output and unstable production including in the Middle East
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said part of the problem with North Korea is related to the US and China trade dispute. (Newswires)

Iran's Supreme Leader Khameni said Tehran should give up hope on Europe to save the nuclear deal following the withdrawal from the US and that Tehran will not negotiate with "indecent" officials in the US at any level. Khameni added that the deal is a means and not the goal which can be abandoned if it does not serve national interests. (Newswires)
 

US

US President Trump said he is optimistic that Canada will join the US & Mexico trade deal and he believes the talks are on track for a Friday deadline. (Newswires)

Canada’s PM Trudeau stated Canada will defend the dairy supply management and he sees a possibility of a NAFTA deal by Friday. There were also comments from Canada’s Foreign Minister Freeland that the latest conversation with US Trade Representative Lighthizer was very productive although she will not discuss details publicly and sees a huge amount of work this week on specifics. (Newswires)

Mexico President Pena Nieto believes they are en-route to reach a trilateral NAFTA deal, while Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said Mexico and the US have negotiated a side letter to the revamped NAFTA on autos & section 232, which guarantees Mexico duty free access under 232 tariffs until certain limits. (Newswires)

US GDP 2nd Estimate Q2 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. 4.1%). (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

The Emini S&P flirted around the 2900 level in early trade but was boosted at the open extending above 2900. Throughout the session gains gradually progressed reaching record highs at 2916. However, some of the gains were pared back as the US cash equity close approached. In terms of earnings, Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE) was higher after an earnings beat, as well as providing guidance higher than expectations. Dick’s Sporting Goods (DKS) was hit after revenues and SSS came in lower than expected, however EPS was a beat; the co. also noted that it’s Under Armour (UAA) sales saw a significant decline which weighed on UAA, as well as Foot Locker (FL). Elsewhere, Morgan Stanley raised Alphabet’s (GOOGL) price target to $1,515 from $1,325, citing a strong core business as well as earnings potential from its Waymo autonomous driving division. The investment bank also raised its price target for Amazon (AMZN) by 35% to $2,500 implying a market value of $1.2trln and keeping its ‘overweight’ rating. Roku (ROKU) were hit after reports Amazon is planning to introduce a free video service for the 48mln users who use its Fire TV streaming video devices. SPX +0.57% at 2914, NDX +1.2% at 7660, DJI +0.2% at 26125.

The complex was pretty much unchanged at settlement with yields higher by less than 1bps across the curve. Volume picked up as European traders got to their desks following reports that Italy would ask the ECB to extend the QE programme though action remained muted for the rest of the session as the 2nd GDP reading as well as weaker pending home sales had minimal impact. 2s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.2bps at settlement. US 10-year T-notes settled unchanged at 120-03.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 29th August 2018 - GBP outperforms in G10 as Barnier hints to a Brexit deal
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries flat, crude up, dollar down.
  • REAR-VIEW: Canada’s Freeland optimistic on deal with US and Mexico; US GDP 2nd Estimate beat; US Pending Home Sales miss; strong 7yr auction, EIA crude headline draw; Iran shortage worries oil market.
  • AHEAD: Salesforce (CRM) earnings and Freeland to meet USTR AMC. Thurs: US PCE Price Index; US Initial Jobless Claims; German State and National CPIs; Canadian GDP; ECB’s Weidmann to speak.

* TRADE: Canada’s Foreign Minister Freeland appeared optimistic and said the latest conversation with US Trade Representative was very productive. She added details will not be discussed publicly and she highlighted there is a huge amount of work to do on specifics this week. She is expected to meet again with the Trade Representative at 5pm ET. White House CEA Chair Hassett, after he urged Canada on Tuesday to get a deal signed with the US and Mexico by Friday claiming the region may lose an opportunity, said there has  been a lot of progress in trade talks with Canada. PM Trudeau reiterated Canada will defend its dairy supply management despite reports overnight which stated the region was reportedly going to make concessions on dairy products (dairy is one of the sticking points amid the renewed NAFTA negotiations). However, President Trump said he is optimistic that Canada will join the US & Mexico trade deal and he believes the talks are on track for a Friday deadline, a view backed by his Mexican and Canadian counterparts. On the Mexican front, Economy Minister Guajardo said they have negotiated a side letter to the revamped NAFTA on autos & section 232 with the US, which guarantees Mexico Duty free access under 232 tariffs until certain limits. It also grants duty free access to current production as well as new plants being constructed and room for growth. On China, WIWO reported the EU is planning a counter-initiative to China's belt and road.

* GEOPOLITICS: A Senior Iranian Military Official stated that if foreign forces in the Strait of Hormuz do not follow international law, they will face "controlling measures" from Iran. This followed yesterday’s comments from Saudi Energy Adviser who noted Iran is unable to completely, or partially, close the strait; similarly Secretary of State Pompeo claimed Iran does not control the channel. Separately, Iran's Supreme Leader Khameni said Tehran should give up hope on Europe to save the nuclear deal following the withdrawal from the US, adding that Tehran will not negotiate with "indecent" officials in the US at any level. He then went on to note the deal is "a means, not the goal" and it can be abandoned if it does not serve national interests; there had been some hope that the Europeans would be able to save the JCPOA, however these latest batch of statements put question to this. Finally, US Secretary of State Pompeo reportedly asked for a meeting with Russia's Lavrov to ease tensions ahead of US sanctions which come into effect in November.

* US GDP: The 2nd Estimate came in stronger than expected at 4.2%, consensus was for 4.0% and prior was revised higher to 4.1%. Higher fixed investment spending and net exports offset the weakness in personal consumption spending. Barclays notes that overall the latest reading does not provide much new to the Q2 growth narrative which sees spending continued to be supported by the fiscal stimulus. However they anticipate a wider trade deficit in the coming quarters on the back of trade tensions, though they see personal and government consumption supporting growth for the remainder of the year.

* PENDING HOME SALES fell in July by 0.7%, expectations were for a rise of 0.3%, reversing most of the gains seen in June. Sales saw a steep fall in the South and the West which dragged down the overall headline; the Northeast and Midwest saw activity picking up. Barclays argues ‘the weak inventory situation of existing homes continues to constrain sales activity’ and add that since 80% of pending home sales will become existing home sales within two months, existing homes sales are likely to follow this trend and move sideways.

* BREXIT: EU's Brexit Negotiator Barnier claimed that the UK’s red lines are being ‘scrupulously’ respected and the bloc is prepared to offer a partnership with the UK, such as has never been with any other 3rd party; the German Foreign Ministry responded to his assertions stating there will be no special rules for a post-Brexit UK. In a Brexit negotiations conference, Brexit Minister Raab appeared confident that a Brexit deal is within sight noting the aim is to reach a deal at the October council but emphasizing there is room for leeway and said he cannot be cavalier about risks of a no deal Brexit.

Regarding a no-deal Brexit, German Finance Minister Scholz stressed it does not represent a solution as the two economies are too closely linked, echoing previous comments from French Finance Minister Le Maire who noted avoiding a hard Brexit in the UK is in the is in EU’s interest as well as Ireland’s Foreign Minister Coveney who does not see anyone benefitting from such an outcome.

* SPX +0.57% at 2914, NDX +1.2% at 7660, DJI +024% at 26125. SECTORS: Energy +0.63%, Materials +0.74%, Industrials +0.08%, Cons Discretionary +1.12%, Cons Staples +0.10%, Healthcare +0.66%, Financials -0.02%, Tech +1.00%, Telecoms -0.75%, Utilities +0.60%.

* FUTURES: The E mini500 flirted around the 2900 level in early trade but was boosted at the open extending above 2900. Throughout the session gains gradually progressed reaching record highs at 2916. However, some of the gains were pared back as the US cash equity close approached.

* EARNINGS: Hewlett Packard Enterprises (HPE) was higher after an earnings beat, as well as providing guidance higher than expectations. Dick’s Sporting Goods (DKS) was hit after revenues and SSS came in lower than expected, however EPS was a beat; the co. also noted that it’s Under Armour (UAA) sales saw a significant decline which weighed on UAA, as well as Foot Locker (FL).

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Morgan Stanley raised Alphabet’s (GOOGL) price target to $1,515 from $1,325, citing a strong core business as well as earnings potential from its Waymo autonomous driving division. The investment bank also raised its price target for Amazon (AMZN) by 35% to $2,500 implying a market value of $1.2trln and keeping its ‘overweight’ rating. Roku (ROKU) were hit after reports Amazon is planning to introduce a free video service for the 48mln users who use its Fire TV streaming video devices.

* WTI CRUDE FUTURES (V8) SETTLE 98C HIGHER AT USD 69.51/BBL; BRENT CRUDE FUTURES (V8) SETTLE USD 1.19 HIGHER AT USD 77.14/BBL

Oil prices moved higher on Wednesday supported by a larger than expected draw in DoE’s inventories of 2.6mln (Exp. drawdown of 690k), driven by stronger demand and falling supply. The breakdown showed Distillates drawing by 0.8mln and Gasoline drawing by 1.6mln, overall contributing to a bullish reading. In news flow, SOMA reported Iraq's August crude exports will be close to 3.595mln BPD (Prev. 3.543 BDP), later confirmed by an official, SOMA also claimed Iraq can raise its oil exports, as it sees the need of more supply on the market. Prices also benefited from reports yesterday that Iran’s oil exports are expected to drop from 2.7mln BPD in June to 1.5mln BPD in September ahead of the US sanctions. A senior Iraqi oil official has also noted OPEC should discuss how to make up for a drop in Iranian oil supply as he sees the oil market facing a big supply shortage post-Iran sanctions. Note OPEC will discuss in December if producers can compensate the supply shortage from Iran. Finally, also placing upside support for the energy complex, Executive Director Birol said to see the oil markets tightening towards end-year citing strong demand and Venezuela's falling output and unstable production including in the Middle East.

* US 10-YEAR T-NOTES SETTLED  UNCHANGED AT 120-03: The complex was pretty much unchanged at settlement with yields higher by less than 1bps across the curve. Volume picked up as European traders got to their desks following reports that Italy would ask the ECB to extend the QE programme though action remained muted for the rest of the session as the 2nd GDP reading as well as weaker pending home sales had minimal impact. 2s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.2bps at settlement.

* 7YR NOTES AUCTION: The US sold $31bln in 7yr notes at a high yield of 2.844%, stopping through by 0.6bps. Demand was strong as the bid-to-cover came in a 2.65x, well above recent averages. Overall a solid auction with directs taking the largest share since December 2016, and dealers were left with the smallest portion since January however indirects took the smallest proportion since March.

*  DXY: An unexpected, albeit marginal upgrade to US Q2 GDP and mostly better than forecast components, have countered a couple of negative month end portfolio rebalancing models (for now at least) to prop up the index and Dollar overall, while compounding gains vs EM currencies that have fallen further in their own right. DXY holding above 94.500, just, within a 94.937-580 range.

* AUD: After last week’s political turmoil and underperformance, the AUD has come under renewed pressure, but this time due to the knock-on effects for domestic consumption and RBA policy from a rise in mortgage rates at West Pac and potential for other lenders feeling the effects of a funding squeeze following suit. AUDUSD has retreated through 0.7300 and back towards recent lows, with AUDNZD under 1.0900 as the Kiwi holds up better near the 0.6700 vs its US counterpart.

* GBP: A Brexit boost for the Pound with Cable back around 1.3000 and EURGBP reversing further from near 0.9100 highs on the back of EU chief negotiator Barnier claiming that the UK’s red lines are being ‘scrupulously’ respected and the bloc is ready to offer Britain a partnership arrangement no other 3rd party has. Cable now testing offers/resistance at 1.3000 having cleared 1.2950, as well as 1.3000 slightly in late trade and the cross is looking at bids/support circa 0.9000.

* CHF: Another G10 outperformer and seemingly on more short position paring rather than anything Swiss of Franc specific, with USDCHF breaking through 0.9700 and EURCHF back under 1.1400.

* EUR: Revisiting 1.1700 vs the USD after the headline pair recoiled towards 1.1650 and through decent option expiry interest at 1.1675 (1.4 bn) in advance of the NY cut, but largely on the coat-tails of Sterling/others.

* JPY, CAD: USDJPY has extended to the upside though chart resistance (111.12) and option expiry related flow (1 bn at 111.20) to test supply at 111.50, while the Loonie just slipped through 1.2950 vs its US rival on NAFTA deal prospects as latest reports suggest a lot of progress in talks between Canadian and US officials.

* EM: Little respite for the Lira and Rand, with USDTRY up towards 6.5000 after only fleeting respite via the CBRT doubling the overnight lending limit for banks, and hardly helped by downbeat date, while USDZAR has rebounded further to 14.4000 following the partial withdrawal or suspension for more consideration of the ANC land appropriation bill.

CHF

Another G10 outperformer and seemingly on more short position paring rather than anything Swiss of Franc specific, with Usd/Chf eyeing 0.9700 and Eur/Chf back under 1.1400.

EUR

Revisiting 1.1700 vs the Usd after the headline pair recoiled towards 1.1650 and through decent option expiry interest at 1.1675 (1.4 bn) in advance of the NY cut, but largely on the coat-tails of Sterling/others (while Eur/Gbp remains above 0.9000 that is!).

JPY/CAD

Usd/Jpy has extended to the upside though chart resistance (111.12) and option expiry related flow (1 bn at 111.20) to test supply at 111.50, while the Loonie is just maintaining keeping its head above 1.2950 vs its US rival on NAFTA deal prospects as latest reports suggest a lot of progress in talks between Canadian and US officials.

EM

Little respite for the Lira and Rand, with Usd/Try up towards 6.4000 after only fleeting respite via the CBRT doubling the overnight lending limit for banks, and hardly helped by downbeat date, while Usd/Zar has rebounded further to 14.4000 following the partial withdrawal or suspension for more consideration of the ANC land appropriation bill.

About 93,000 people worldwide received the ASR implants, with roughly 4,700 of them in India, according to a panel.  (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Freeport (FCX) – Indonesia is to extend the co.’s special mining permit by one month to September. (Newswires)
  • Garmin (GRMN) – The co. acquires FltPlan.com; terms not disclosed. (Newswires)

  • US automakers (F, FCAU, TM) – The new US-Mexico trade deal includes a cap on autos made in Mexico entering the US allowing US representatives to impose a 25% tariff above 2.5mln units of auto parts. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) – Morgan Stanley raises its price target by 35% to USD 2,500 implying a market value of USD 1.2trln and keeping its ‘overweight’ rating.  The retail giant is planning to introduce a free video service for the 48mln users who use its Fire TV streaming video devices, Of note for Roku (ROKU). Separately, it hires former ESPN executive Marie Donoghue, CNBC reports. The co. expands Whole Foods’ grocery delivery through Prime Now to Columbus, Dayton, Portland, Greater Washington D.C. and additional areas of New York City. (Newswires/CNBC)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media company is rolling out its watch video service internationally, one year after it was introduced in the US, transmitting sports and news competing with others such as YouTube (GOOGL).  Separately, more than 100 employees have formed an online group against “anyone who presents a view that appears to be in opposition to left-leaning ideology". (NY Post/Newswires)

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to auction USD 31bln of 7-year notes on 29 August 2018 at 1300 EST/1800 BST
content: this week, with all settling on 31 August. The Fed will add on USD 2.5bln of 2s to its SOMA portfolio, USD 2.6bln of 5s, and USD 2.2bln of 7s. In the 7-year secto, demand has been edging down, as measured by bid-to-cover ratios, with the last auction covered 2.49x versus the 2018 monthly average of 2.55x. “Despite slightly weaker demand, auction performance has held up pretty well in the past few months,” Barclays says, “the last two auctions (July and June) have stopped at the 1pm WI levels, while the two auctions prior to that stopped through.” Domestic investors are the largest participants at the 7-year auctions taking around 60% over the last few auctions, Barclays notes, with foreign bidders taking between 10-15% (from levels near 20% at the beginning of the year). “The new 7y is unlikely to be the cheapest-to-deliver in 10-year (Dec’18) future, assuming a 2.75% coupon and current yield levels,” Barclays says, “However, if yields rise heading into the auction, the issue could price at a 2.875% coupon and become the new cheapest-to-deliver.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 29th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities trade on the backfoot (Eurostoxx 50 -0.5%) with underperformance in Spain’s IBEX (-1.0%)
  • The DXY and broad Dollar continue to consolidate off recent lows on the back of Monday’s upbeat US consumer confidence survey
  • UK and EU officials are said to view mid-November as the new Brexit deal deadline and are said to view an agreement by October as unlikely
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US GDP (2nd estimate), Pending Home Sales, DoEs, and supply from the US

ASIA-PAC

Asia-Pac stocks traded mixed following the unconvincing performance on Wall St whereby the majors somewhat flatlined in which the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Comp. just about eked fresh record highs. ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were positive with Australia led higher by resilience in financials and as earnings dominated news flow, while the Japanese benchmark was supported by mild JPY weakness and briefly reclaimed the 22900 level. Conversely, Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) was negative and Hang Seng (+0.2%) traded indecisive following continued PBoC liquidity inaction and amid a slew of earnings including 3 of China’s big 4 banks which all posted growth in profits. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the heightened risk appetite in Japan and following a relatively paltry Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8072 (Prev. 6.8052)

Westpac (WBC AT) raised variable mortgage rates due to an increase in wholesale funding costs; loan rate raised by 14bps to 5.38%. (Newswires)

US

Canada is said to be prepared to make concessions on dairy for NAFTA. In separate news, US-Mexico trade deal provides a potential cap on Mexican cars shipped to the US and would allow the US to impose punitive tariffs of as much as 25% on auto-related imports that exceed certain volumes according to sources. (Globe and Mail/Newswires)

EU/UK

UK and EU officials are said to view mid-November as the new Brexit deal deadline and are said to view an agreement by October as unlikely. (Newswires)

UK's Brexit Secretary Raab has expressed his frustration over EU's Chief Negotiator Barnier's alleged failure to make himself available for face-to-face talks. (The Guardian)

UK PM May has announced she will defend herself against any potential leadership challenge from Boris Johnson and fully intends to lead the Conservatives into the next General election. (Newswires)

Remain-supporting Conservatives have reported an noticeable increase in applications to join their local parties, leading to fears that they are being targeted by Ukip supporters in a plot to unseat them and elect a Brexit-supporting PM to replace May. (Times)

TURKEY

Turkish Central Bank said it has doubled banks' borrowing limit for overnight transactions at the interbank money market. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities trade on the backfoot (Eurostoxx 50 -0.5%) with underperformance in Spain’s IBEX (-1.0%) following a downgrade of its second largest constituents, Inditex (-4.6%), subsequently weighing on the consumer discretionary sector. Energy names underperform, dragging down the likes of oil names such as Shell (-1.3%), in turn weighing on the FTSE 100 (-0.8%), while industrial names benefit from the decline in oil and base metal prices. In terms of individual movers, RTL group (+5.0%) flew to the top of the Stoxx 600 after reporting strong earnings.

FX

AUD - Back down towards 0.7300 vs its US counterpart and 1.0900 on the NZD cross after a funding-related hike in mortgage rates by West Pac sparked all round selling on the premise that the squeeze on borrowers will crimp disposable income and hit spending, with the RBA even more inclined to maintain policy accommodation or even forced to cut rates as a result. 

DXY - The index and broad Dollar continue to consolidate off recent lows on the back of Monday’s upbeat US consumer confidence survey that sparked short covering, and ahead of today’s 2nd look at Q2 GDP that is expected to confirm strong growth. However, a wider than forecast advance trade balance for July could adversely impact, while at least one month end rebalancing model indicates a strong Usd sell signal. DXY currently nearer the upper end of a 94.890-685 range.

EUR - The single currency remains capped below 1.1700 vs the Greenback having relinquished big figure-plus status yesterday amidst offers between 1.1725-30 and with decent option expiry interest at the 1.1675 strike (1.4 bn) weighing.

SEK - Another G10 underperformer and on follow-through selling in wake of Tuesday’s dire Swedish retail sales data that could be acknowledged by the Riksbank next week in some shape or form, ie policy guidance and/or through the rate path. Eur/Sek up to 10.7000+ multi-year peaks, and looking at 10.7900 chart resistance above.

GBP/CAD/JPY/CHF/NZD - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, with Cable hovering above 1.2850, but unable to retest 1.2900 due to ongoing Brexit uncertainty and Tory in-fighting as PM May and Chancellor Hammond cross swords over the budget. Meanwhile, the Loonie has lost some of its initial NAFTA momentum to slip back below 1.2900 against its US peer, even though reports suggest that Canada may we willing to offer dairy concessions. Usd/Jpy remains just over the 111.00 level and also close to option expiry interest (1 bn at 111.20), with the 55 DMA at 111.05 being eyed as pivotal from a technical perspective. The Kiwi is keeping tabs on 0.6700 and Franc holds the bulk of its recent gains within 0.9775-60 parameters, largely ignoring a sharp deterioration in Swiss ZEW investor sentiment, or rather heeding the bleak news.

EM - The Lira and Rand continue to bear the brunt of the currency run and capital flight for all the well know reasons, with Usd/Try up towards 6.4000 after only fleeting respite via the CBRT doubling the overnight lending limit for banks, while Usd/Zar has rebounded further to 14.4000 following the partial withdrawal or suspension for more consideration of the ANC land appropriation bill.

FIXED INCOME

Core debt futures still look somewhat reticent, but should have no issues on the supply front given a solid Bobl tap by all the usual metrics used to gauge the success of a cash offering. The 5 year contract is just off a new Eurex intraday base of 131.95, however, vs 132.06 at best and 132.01 at the previous close, with Bunds also nearer their 162.43 low (-9 ticks and 21 ticks off the high) and Gilts just recovering 123.00+ status from 122.95 (-6 ticks vs +18 ticks at the Liffe high). Elsewhere, US Treasuries are middling vs overnight ranges and the curve is a tad flatter in the run up to US GDP and pending home sales dat, anda before 2 year FRNs and 7 year notes go under the hammer.

COMMODITIES

Commodities trade higher, WTI futures breached its 100 DMA to the upside(at USD 68.69/bbl), while Brent reclaimed the USD 76/bbl level after it losing following a surprise build in API crude inventories last night. The recent gains in WTI and Brent followed comments from IEA's Executive Director Birol, he sees oil markets tightening towards end-year, while citing strong demand, Venezuela's falling output and unstable production including in the Middle East. Traders will be eyeing the EIA weekly crude stocks due later today, expected to print a draw of 686K barrels; according to a Reuters poll.

Elsewhere, gold is uneventful as the yellow metal tracks the USD, while Shanghai steel dropped for a sixth consecutive session following comments from Beijing’s state planner, warning the economy is facing increasing risks in the second half of the year. However, some analysts believe steel prices will be supported by production curbs as Beijing tries to limit pollution.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks +38k vs. Exp. -700k (Prev. -5.170mln). (Newswires)

DXY currently nearer the upper end of a 94.890-685 range.

EUR - The single currency remains capped below 1.1700 vs the Greenback having relinquished big figure-plus status yesterday amidst offers between 1.1725-30 and with decent option expiry interest at the 1.1675 strike (1.4 bn) weighing.

SEK - Another G10 underperformer and on follow-through selling in wake of Tuesday’s dire Swedish retail sales data that could be acknowledged by the Riksbank next week in some shape or form, ie policy guidance and/or through the rate path. Eur/Sek up to 10.7000+ multi-year peaks, and looking at 10.7900 chart resistance above.

GBP/CAD/JPY/CHF/NZD - All narrowly mixed vs the Usd, with Cable hovering above 1.2850, but unable to retest 1.2900 due to ongoing Brexit uncertainty and Tory in-fighting as PM May and Chancellor Hammond cross swords over the budget. Meanwhile, the Loonie has lost some of its initial NAFTA momentum to slip back below 1.2900 against its US peer, even though reports suggest that Canada may we willing to offer dairy concessions. Usd/Jpy remains just over the 111.00 level and also close to option expiry interest (1 bn at 111.20), with the 55 DMA at 111.05 being eyed as pivotal from a technical perspective. The Kiwi is keeping tabs on 0.6700 and Franc holds the bulk of its recent gains within 0.9775-60 parameters, largely ignoring a sharp deterioration in Swiss ZEW investor sentiment, or rather heeding the bleak news.

EM - The Lira and Rand continue to bear the brunt of the currency run and capital flight for all the well know reasons, with Usd/Try up towards 6.4000 after only fleeting respite via the CBRT doubling the overnight lending limit for banks, while Usd/Zar has rebounded further to 14.4000 following the partial withdrawal or suspension for more consideration of the ANC land appropriation bill.

FIXED INCOME

Core debt futures still look somewhat reticent, but should have no issues on the supply front given a solid Bobl tap by all the usual metrics used to gauge the success of a cash offering. The 5 year contract is just off a new Eurex intraday base of 131.95, however, vs 132.06 at best and 132.01 at the previous close, with Bunds also nearer their 162.43 low (-9 ticks and 21 ticks off the high) and Gilts just recovering 123.00+ status from 122.95 (-6 ticks vs +18 ticks at the Liffe high). Elsewhere, US Treasuries are middling vs overnight ranges and the curve is a tad flatter in the run up to US GDP and pending home sales dat, anda before 2 year FRNs and 7 year notes go under the hammer.

COMMODITIES

Commodities trade higher, WTI futures breached its 100 DMA to the upside(at USD 68.69/bbl), while Brent reclaimed the USD 76/bbl level after it losing following a surprise build in API crude inventories last night. Traders will be eyeing the EIA weekly crude stocks due later today, expected to print a draw of 686K barrels; according to a Reuters poll.

Elsewhere, gold is uneventful as the yellow metal tracks the USD, while Shanghai steel dropped for a sixth consecutive session following comments from Beijing’s state planner, warning the economy is facing increasing risks in the second half of the year. However, some analysts believe steel prices will be supported by production curbs as Beijing tries to limit pollution.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 29th August 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asia-Pac stocks traded mixed following the unconvincing performance on Wall St whereby the majors somewhat flatlined
  • In FX, CAD was underpinned by trade hopes on reports that Canada was said to be prepared to make concessions on dairy for NAFTA
  • UK and EU officials are said to view mid-November as the new Brexit deal deadline and are said to view an agreement by October as unlikely
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US GDP (2nd estimate), Pending Home Sales, DoEs, supply from Germany and the US

ASIA

Asia-Pac stocks traded mixed following the unconvincing performance on Wall St whereby the majors somewhat flatlined in which the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Comp. just about eked fresh record highs. ASX 200 (+0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.3%) were positive with Australia led higher by resilience in financials and as earnings dominated news flow, while the Japanese benchmark was supported by mild JPY weakness and briefly reclaimed the 22900 level. Conversely, Shanghai Comp. (-0.4%) was negative and Hang Seng (+0.2%) traded indecisive following continued PBoC liquidity inaction and amid a slew of earnings including 3 of China’s big 4 banks which all posted growth in profits. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the heightened risk appetite in Japan and following a relatively paltry Rinban announcement by the BoJ.

PBoC skipped open market operations and are net neutral on the day. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8072 (Prev. 6.8052)


UK/EU

UK PM May refused to say whether she thinks the UK will be better or worse off in the event of a 'no-deal' Brexit and stated the government is working to make a success of leaving the EU "whatever the outcome of the negotiations". (Sky)

UK and EU officials are said to view mid-November as the new Brexit deal deadline and are said to view an agreement by October as unlikely. (Newswires)

UK PM May has announced she will defend herself against any potential leadership challenge from Boris Johnson and fully intends to lead the Conservatives into the next General election. (Newswires)

Remain-supporting Conservatives have reported an noticeable increase in applications to join their local parties, leading to fears that they are being targeted by Ukip supporters in a plot to unseat them and elect a Brexit-supporting PM to replace May. (Times)

Ireland’s Foreign Minister Coveney said chances of a no deal Brexit are very slim as no one would benefit and that it is possible to get a deal on Brexit well before the year-end, while Coveney added that talks of surviving a no deal Brexit is more of a negotiation tactic than a reality. (Newswires)

UK BRC Shop Price Index (Jul) Y/Y 0.1% (Prev. -0.3%). (Newswires)


FX

Price action across the FX space was mostly muted amid a lack of data points, although the greenback marginally extended on its rebound which recently dragged EUR/USD below the 1.1700 handle, while GBP/USD languished near the prior day’s lows. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were higher on safe-haven outflows amid strength in Tokyo stock markets, while CAD was underpinned by trade hopes on reports that Canada was said to be prepared to make concessions on dairy for NAFTA.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were lacklustre overnight in which WTI crude futures consolidated after the prior day’s decline which was triggered by a rebound in the greenback and surprise miniscule build in API inventories. Elsewhere, gold attempted to nurse some of its recent losses after having found support at the USD 1200/oz level, while copper was kept rangebound alongside the mixed risk tone.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks +38k vs. Exp. -700k (Prev. -5.170mln). (Newswires)

Iran oil shipments are reportedly declining at a faster-than-expected pace ahead of US sanctions which begin in November, while Iran reportedly expects crude exports to fall by a third in September. (WSJ)

Mexico's incoming government is mulling an 'indefinite' suspension of competitive auctions for oil and gas producers and Pemex venture partners and is to consider withdrawing IEA and forge closer ties with OPEC, according to a document. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of Defense Mattis suggested the US could resume military drills in the Korean peninsula which were suspended after the Trump-Kim summit, in which he stated that the US had no plans at this time to suspend any more exercises. (Axios)


US

Fed Discount Rate Minutes stated 2 Regional banks supported a hike at the July meeting and 10 backed no changes to the discount rate. Furthermore, the minutes noted that Kansas City (George) and Cleveland (Mester) urged raising discount rate by 0.25% due to the continued solid economic growth outlook, tight labour markets and inflation remaining near 2%, but the remaining 10 wanted to maintain as they felt it was appropriate during the current economic conditions. (Newswires)

US Senate confirmed Richard Clarida for Fed vice-chair. (Newswires)

Canada is said to be prepared to make concessions on dairy for NAFTA. In separate news, US-Mexico trade deal provides a potential cap on Mexican cars shipped to the US and would allow the US to impose punitive tariffs of as much as 25% on auto-related imports that exceed certain volumes according to sources. (Globe and Mail/Newswires)

US Commerce Secretary Ross said the US is asking Canada to consider joining the US-Mexico trade deal but also noted that Canada has made troubles in drugs and biologics for US firms, while he also stated that the US is not accusing Mexico of currency manipulation as the MXN has been falling which impacts US trade deficit. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said his position on supply hasn't changed but looks forward to a NAFTA deal if it is good for Canada, while he added there has been progress on autos and Canada is studying the US-Mexico terms of the deal. Elsewhere, Canadian Foreign Minister Freeland said we are encouraged by progress between US and Mexico in which progress on autos and labor were particularly helpful, while Freeland later stated they had a very constructive meeting with US Trade Representative Lighthizer and will return on Wednesday to resume discussions. (Newswires)

White House Economist Hasset said the clock is ticking for Canada and that if Canada doesn’t sign on by Friday, “the train might start to leave the station”. (Newswires)

US Senate Majority Leader McConnell said the trade deal between US & Mexico is not a bad agreement and added the Senate has to wait until interactions with Canada are complete before making forward judgement. Elsewhere, US Senate Majority Leader McConnell is also said to hope to get the spending bill to President Trump by September. (Newswires)
